top_comment.text:
Mr. Harris, I totally agree about the boy-racer looking, mini GT3 rear 
wing. That's why when I am going to become an SLS owner in short time, I'm 
going to go to AMG's in-house customization center and order an SLS 
gullwing door car, silver with red interior, and black or red brake 
calipers in place of those tacky yellow ones, but with all the go-fast 
elements of an SLS AMG Black Series, but with none of the aero bits, just 
the gorgeous regular SLS AMG body which is a pretty much perfect modern-day 
interpretation of the 1950's 300SL gullwing cars. A well deserved treat for 
myself after the better part of 30 years as an aerospace engineer, keeping 
Boeing and Airbus commercial airliners flying and making upgraded spares 
for the F-15 Eagle/Strike Eagle.﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: Shahzad Khan

comments.text:
+assassinneo We have Black Series SLSs here in the 'States. The cars are 
street legal. And just like with any powerful car, people can have them, 
but they would face consequences for something like being pulled over for 
speeding or racing on the street. But we have drag strips and track days to 
really allow us to drive our cars hard. And occasionally people do canyon 
runs where they drive a little faster than the speed limit, if you know 
what I mean. A co-worker of mine has an F430, and he tells me stories about 
how he and his buddies get pretty crazy speed-wise on some of the canyon 
roads here in Southern California. So, sadly, we do have a speed limit, but 
if someone drives the pants off their car and doesn't hurt anyone or get 
nailed by the cops, then fun will be had. Luckily, here in the 'States, we 
don't have the sort of fun-killing speed cameras that the Brits do. So 
here, if you drive hard in the canyons and don't get caught, then 
everything is good. And again, we have drag strips and track days if we 
want to attend those and get actual times driving on a real track.

And I know there is an aero benefit from the aero parts on a Black Series, 
however I don't think I'll ever be driving so quick that the benefits of 
the aero would have much of an impact. And even if there is a great aero 
benefit from those pieces, I would make the trade to have a regular SLS 
body over a Black Series because the lines of the "regular" SLS AMG are 
gorgeous, and like I said before, almost a perfect modern day 
interpretation of the 300SL gullwing cars of the '50s. I would gladly give 
up the aero benefits of the big splitter, canards, boy-racer-looking mini 
GT3 fixed rear wing, etc, to have the classy, clean lines of a "regular" 
SLS AMG. And it would be a unique "sleeper." The body would suggest regular 
SLS AMG, however under the body work, it's all Black Series. Motor, lighter 
backbone, titanium exhaust, suspension...all the non-aero go fast parts of 
a Black Series with the clean lines of a "regular" SLS.

If I were to take the car to Willow Springs here in California, and raced 
around the fasted of the three tracks (Big Willow), I think the differences 
in lap times between a car like I want and a full on Black Series would be 
negligible. Even if the Black Series was 5 seconds quicker (which it 
probably wouldn't be), I'd still rather have the custom job.

This is a car I'm going to be taking to work, and I really don't want my 
coworkers seeing me drive around in a Black Series with that fixed mini GT3 
rear wing, canards, etc. To them, it would just appear to be a nice clean 
Mercedes SLS AMG, but with the grunt of all the Black Series internal 
go-fast parts of a Black Series.

And I see you're a fellow BMW fan as well. Am I right when I say that the 
more performance minded models (like the M cars) are incredibly fun to 
drive?

I mean look what has happened to the original E30 M3 (from the '80s, for 
those who don't know). They used to be cars one could buy for a few 
thousand dollars. Now they are going for 40k on average. Word is that the 
same thing is going to happen with the E46 M3. The price spike is going to 
skip the E36 M3s and the numbers for E46 M3s, which can be had now for 
about 12-15k, are going to skyrocket as well, into that same sort of 40k 
price range that E30 M3s go for nowadays.
comments.author: Sandra Rios

comments.text:
+Sandra Rios  I'm just curious what are you going to do with SLS BS without 
the body kit? The body kit is not just for better look, but also for aero 
dynamics and stability, you should know that. Also I assume you are an US 
citizen, and as far as I know these cars are no use for streets, because of 
the speed limits. In my country (Bulgaria) speed limits are just like 
warning signs. Everybody drives at the speed limits his car is capable of, 
no matter the road and conditions. On the other hand it's a proper choice 
if you're gonna use it on a track. As for the BMWs I agree, as fan and 
owner I'd say BMWs give you pretty good experience on the road and on the 
track even if it's just stock.
comments.author: assassinneo

comments.text:
+viktorftw You're right for the most part. But I don't think you're giving 
BMW or the i8 enough credit. Firstly, BMWs, particularly the E46 M3 and the 
first-gen M Roadster are amazing cars to drive. If you haven't driven a 
performance (M) BMW, I definitely recommend it and I think you would change 
your mind about BMWs.

And with the i8, it's not just about the styling or not being a track 
monster, it's about the concept of having a car that can hold it's own at 
a track day and it's a green sport-hybrid with 357 hp and 400+ lbs./ft. of 
torque. And emissions-wise, it would be nice knowing I would be doing my 
part for Mother Earth. i8s only emit 50g of CO2/kilometer. An average human 
being emits the same amount of CO2 with 50 breaths!

So, with the i8 option, it's more about balancing having a fun car that is 
green. The other two (and a used 458) are also great options, but that's if 
I want to go all and out track monster.

Yeah, so we kind of agree. But again, if you've driven one of BMWs M cars, 
you would not get out of it thinking it has no soul to it. BMW may seem all 
typical "German efficiency," but the cars themselves have a lot of soul. 
They are torque monsters. Like with an E46 M3 for example, there is no need 
for a downshift if you want to pass someone on the highway. Just put your 
foot down, even at low revs, and the tach needle speeds to redline. 
"Ultimate Driving Machine" right? If you were to drive the right BMWs, 
you'd see that BMW isn't overstating things with that tag line. Some of 
them may not be the quickest cars, but the driving experience is awesome. 
It's kind of like how driving an MX-5 lets one drive the car hard and feel 
like they are going superfast, but are actually going reasonable speeds. 
Certain BMWs are like that, but with more power.

Thanks for the advice though about a used 458. I hadn't even thought of 
that. Now the decision is tougher! ☺
comments.author: Sandra Rios

comments.text:
+Sandra Rios Yeah, I understand and I totally know how difficult it is to 
buy yourself a new car.

 When I bought my E63 AMG I considered buying a GTR instead but the 5 seats 
and comfort + the sound of the E63 made it a clear choice for me. It 
depends what you are out after, do you want a monster machine that sounds 
like godzillas dad and looks stunning + is an eyecatcher I would not even 
think about it and go for the SLS.
GT3 is a great driving machine and porsche only makes quality cars. 

I8 for me is a little boring even if it looks like a space machine compared 
to the others, but its not a driving monster machine like the others, feels 
like it has no soul.

Btw tbh I would buy a used ferrari 458, its a great car for the price.

First: SLS
Second:GT3
Third:i8
comments.author: viktorftw

comments.text:
+viktorftw Yeah, if people want to see what kind of brakes I have, they can 
look closely lol.

On the i8 vs. SLS thing, I've been in the aerospace field for 30 years and 
I've recently amassed some money to treat myself to a nice machine 
using stocks, gambling, etc., and my cap is 300k.

Right now I really am up in the air about what to choose. It's between the 
custom SLS, a new Porsche GT3, or an i8. Each has it's special qualities, 
which is making the decision so hard, but, again, I really don't know which 
one I'm gonna go with. I said I was thinking i8 last time because I had 
just finished looking at tons of pics of the i8 that looks like a car from 
25 years from now, and it's an incredibly capable sport-hybrid. Those are 
two big pluses, and it would leave me with plenty of cash to maybe buy a 
second, cheaper used machine.

I really don't know, but I totally understand when you say you'd take the 
SLS over an i8. That's what's making this decision so difficult!
comments.author: Sandra Rios

comments.text:
+Sandra Rios Yepp, I do understand that you want to make it custom and dont 
care what other people think. Porsche and other brands also use yellow to 
"show" the carbon ceramic brakes, dunno why it is like that but I like the 
yellow ones anyway! 
Never ever would I take an i8 over the SLS ;)
comments.author: viktorftw

comments.text:
+viktorftw I found that out when I was doing my research, but I could care 
less what sort of brakes people think my car has. For purely aesthetic 
reasons, I'd want either black calipers, red, or steel-look. If people see 
the red calipers and assume the car has steel brakes, I don't care. The red 
would be to match the red interior.

But that's if I choose to go with my custom SLS. I am really thinking of 
going with an i8 instead.

But thanks for the post and sharing with other people what the different 
color brake calipers mean. Have a good one!
comments.author: Sandra Rios

comments.text:
+Sandra Rios The yellow brake calipers shows ppl that you have carbon 
cemaric brakes. The red ones on AMG cars are steel brakes :)
comments.author: viktorftw

comments.text:
+C6SuperchargedZR1 Actually, I've already spoken with people at AMG and 
they told me they could do the conversion with a pre-owned car. So 
basically, all the Black Series go fast stuff, like I was saying, as in the 
motor, back bone, suspension, etc. None, of the aero (no boy-racer mini GT3 
wing, no front splitter nothing). Just something that looks like a regular 
SLS AMG with it's gorgeous lines, but a Black Series underneath the 
bodywork. And it can all be done within my price range. So I can have my 
"regular" SLS AMG gullwing door car with it's gorgeous lines that is an 
almost perfect modern day interpretation of the 300SL gullwing door cars of 
the '50s, but it's all Black Series under the bodywork. Go ahead and call 
if you like.

You can call if you want. AMG can do anything if you put up the money. And 
they told me such a car would be simple compared to the custom stuff 
they've done for Sheiks, etc. from places like Abu Dhabi.

Ferrari does the same thing. Have you seen some of the custom jobs they've 
done for the people who shelled out the cash?
comments.author: Sandra Rios

comments.author: C6SuperchargedZR1

comments.text:
+yvonne sanchez Thanks. As for the studying aerospace engineering, it might 
seem tough at times, but the technology you'll be working with like CFD was 
something my generation had to adapt to. When I started, we still relied on 
wind tunnels and models as our best guess at a result.

But if you're studying it now, they're going to teach you all about CFD and 
all the newer computer stuff. All I can say is don't give up. It's a 
challenging and rewarding career.

Lol, I can remember when CAD/CAM seemed like the most amazing thing ever 
and there was no way such technology could be topped.

And I'm pretty sure they're still gonna teach you the older stuff, 
the fundamentals. Depending on who you go to work for, you might still well 
be using wind tunnels along with CFD.

But nowadays there's rapid prototyping, CFD, more advanced CAD/CAM. I'm not 
saying those things are going to make things a walk in the park, they are 
tools that your bosses are gonna expect you use to come out with the latest 
and greatest possible.

But yeah, it's a great career, lot's a challenges, even some fun, lot's of 
fulfillment, so just keep studying!
comments.author: Sandra Rios

comments.text: That is awesome! I'm currently studying aerospace engineering, any tips?

captions.text:
The new SLS AMG Black Series
is the fastest, most
hardcore AMG ever.

It costs 230,000 pounds, weighs
1,550 kilograms, has

631 horsepower, and, on track,
intends to ingest GT3 RS's.
This is Paul Ricard Circuit.

And we're not paying
for tires.
Let's start with the chassis.

Pretty much every aspect
has been improved or
sharpened for the track.

The front track itself is
20 millimeters wider.

The rear is 24 millimeters
wider.

The springs and dampers
are stiffer.
The wheel carriers are new.

The wheels are wider and use
sticky Michelin Pilot Sport
Cup 2 rubber.

Being a Black Series, the body
work's been mildly inflated--

13 millimeters wider at the
front, 26 wider at the rear.

There are spoilers and diffusers
to reduce lift, and

it has to be said, a
slightly apologetic
adjustable rear wing.

The motor is the classic
M156 6.2 liter V8.

And this is its last night on
beers before everything is
turbo charged.
Boo!

But there's new valve gear, a
trick intake with shorter

runners, bigger bearings,
and a new oil system.

It likes to rev to 8 now, and
that means it actually loses

nine foot pounds of torque
to the standard motor.

Gear shifts have been
made faster.

The gear box sits
a little lower.

There are proper bucket seats,
and, well, it's now 17
kilograms lighter overall.
And this is how.

Quite often, at launch events
you end up with a load of

useless tat on display that
means absolutely nothing.

But in the case of this Black
Series, they've been quite

helpful because they've shown us
the parts that shed all of
the weight.

So first of all, ignore the
cutaway and follow me.
Exhaust systems.

That one there, stainless
steel.
Very nice, but heavy.
This one here, titanium.
